content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a risk-averse undergraduate student, I would prefer to choose a strategy that maximizes security and certainty over potential gains. In this game, if both players consistently pick the same option (either R or B), we can earn a consistent payoff. If we play it safe by choosing B, we have a guaranteed return of 20$ in every round where our opponent also chooses B. This accounts for 50 out of 75 rounds, as both players cannot choose the same option simultaneously (since there are only two options).

However, there are 25 remaining rounds where our payoff can be increased if we deviate from the safe choice. In each of those rounds, if we switch our strategy and pick R when our opponent chooses B, we can earn 40$ instead of 20$. Since we value security and certainty over potential gains, we should stick to our initial strategy (picking B) in the majority of rounds. To ensure that the opportunity for increased payoff in those 25 deviating rounds does not compromise our overall goal of maximizing safety and consistency, I would choose a mixed strategy where I pick R in around 10 out of the 75 rounds. This will help to maintain the element of surprise and take advantage of any potential opportunities while still prioritizing security and certainty in the majority of the game.

So, as a human player with risk-averse preferences, I would choose B{B} for this lab experiment.
